greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array of a(n)=a(n-1)*k-((k-1)/(k^n)) where a(0)=1 and k=(sqrt(x^2-1)+x)^2 for integers x>=1.
comment: Conjecture: Given function f(x, y)=(sqrt(x^2+y)+x)^2; constant k=f(x, y); and initial term a(0)=1; then for all integers x>=1 and y=[+-]1, k may be irrational, but sequence a(n)=a(n-1)*k-((k-1)/(k^n)) always produces integer sequences; y=-1 results shown here; y=1 results are A188647.
Also square array A(n,k), n >= 1, k >= 0, read by antidiagonals, where A(n,k) is (1/n) * T_{2*k+1}(n), with the Chebyshev polynomials of the first kind (type T). - _Seiichi Manyama_, Jan 01 2019
link: Index entries for sequences related to Chebyshev polynomials.
mathematica: Table[A[n-k, k], {n, 1, 9}, {k, n-1, 0, -1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jan 02 2019, after _Seiichi Manyama_ *)
xref: Cf. A188644, A188647 (f(x, y) as above with y=1).
results.author: _Charles L. Hohn_, Apr 06 2011
ext: Edited and extended by _Seiichi Manyama_, Jan 01 2019
